definition[0]: a system in which the government decides the prices of things
definition[1]: an agreement between producers and sellers of a product to set its price at a high level
definition[2]: when companies in an industry agree on the prices they will charge for something. This form of price-fixing is done so that companies avoid competing with each other, and is normally illegal
example[0]: The EU investigated international telephone agreements to see if there was price-fixing in violation of EU competition rules.
example[1]: Japan’s Fair Trade Commission ordered 13 ink makers to break up a price-fixing cartel (=arrangement between a group of companies).
definition[3]: when a company tells the shops etc that sell its products how much they must charge for them. This form of price-fixing is sometimes illegal
example[2]: The UK’s last price-fixing arrangement was retail price maintenance for non-prescription medicines.
definition[4]: when a government decides the price at which something should be sold
example[3]: government price-fixing for the sale of drugs to the National Health Service
